section.title: When to use?
section.para: Whenever possible use the common schema, called dk-schema.rnc to validate the files, variants such as cookery are authored separately but it is still possible to validate such variant using the common schema file.

section.title: DK Common Attributes
section.para: xml:id attribute is used to provide a unique identifier for a given block.
DK Schema allows for a set of attributes that can be used anywhere in the XML structure.
These attributes are Docbook common attributes and DK specific attributes.
condition and cref attributes are used for profiling (marking content for a specific use). Refer to for more details.
lat and lon are used to associate geocoding information. Refer to for more details.
rend attribute is used to provide strictly presentational hints to the rendering system. Refer to for more details.
metaref attribute is used to link to additional metadata about the subject. Refer to for more details.
role attribute is used to classify portions of the content. Refer to for more details.

linkend attribute should be used whenever possible for linking between parts of the document in elements such as link and xref. In more advanced scenarios, such as linking to external documents it is possible to use Xlink specification and specifically xlink:href attribute instead of linkend.

section.title: Address elements
section.para: The standard Docbook elements address (and constituent elements - street, city, state, country, pob, postcode, otheraddr) should be used.
The Docbook elements (street, city etc) as well as additional elements: phone, fax, email are allowed inside the address wrapper.
Where necessary, single, inline address elements can be used, wrapped within an address element
In addition to the standard Docbook constraints, please follow these rules:

listitem.para: Use otheraddr to mark up the post box number.
Use pob to indicate auxillary information about the address, such as the house name, or "last house on the left".

Use street element to indicate street and house or flat number.Put street name and number together, the way it should be displayed in a given country, for example "34 Temple Grove" in the UK or "Roosevelta 4" in Poland. Avoid using abbreviated form such as "High st.", use the full name, for example "High Street"
Use city element to indicate city, town, village, settlement. If necessary use metaref attribute to indicate the accurate description of the type of the place.

Use state element to indicate state, region, county, province, canton, territory and similar geographical distinctions. If necessary use metaref attribute to indicate the accurate gographical description of the type of the place.

Use postcode element to indicate postcode, zipcode or equivalent alphanumeric definition of an area. Avoid using dashes or characters that are not part of the post code itself. If necessary use metaref attribute to indicate the type of the code, for example metaref="zipcode".
Use country element to indicate the country of an address. If necessary use metaref attribute with ISO-3166 alpha 2 for country classification, for example metaref="GB"

Use phone element to indicate the telephone for a given address. If necessary use metaref attribute with ISO-3166 alpha 2 to indicate country code, for example metaref="GB". Avoid including the country code in the number - this can be generated in the output programatically.

Use uri element for markup if the place described also has an address on the Internet. Do not include the protocol prefix (http:// or http://) and avoid including the www. prefix, if the website works without it. See for more details on marking-up URIs.

section.para: If it is necessary to collect the address in the form "Address Line Number 1, Line 2" or to output it in the same form, map the line numbers to the semantically appropriate DK Schema elements for example street or if the is no clear match, use otheraddr and use XML document order to preserve the address Line numbering.

In cases, where more detailed, or custom descriptions of address may be necessary, use additional phrase elements with a role attribute inside an address or develop a taxonomy and use metaref attribute instead of role.
The following attributes from the Docbook v5.x Schema: continuation, format, linenumbering are not allowed.

section.title: Date
section.para: Dates should be captured using a phrase element, with a role="date" attribute value.
For date ranges, see .
For more descriptive tagging options see

section.title: Directory
section.para: Content that contains a directory of contact addresses, further information, phone book listing etc. should be captured with a role attribute indicating a directory entry container element.

Use section with a role="directory" attribute if the directory exists as a top-level entry in the structure of the book or section with a role="directory" attribute if the directory exists below the chapter level.
Individual entries should be captured using a block level element such as section with a role="dir_entry" attribute.
Directory can be further subdivided using a block level element such as section with a role="dir_section" attribute.
A directory listing containing referential type of information should be captured using section elements with a role attribute indicating a directory entry container element.

section.title: Table of Contents
section.para: Under normal circumstances, Table of Contents should not be captured by hand. Instead, the structure of the book must be captured using a hierarchy of parts, chapters and sections. The Table of Contents will be automatically generated from that.
If there is a specific case where an alternative Table of Contents needs to be produced that does not reflect the hierarchy of the XML, use toc element.

section.title: Index
section.para: If it is desirable to auto-generate an index, individual terms may be marked-up at the point-of-reference in the text using the indexterm element.
Otherwise, capture the index using the index element inside a book or part element.

section.title: Set element
section.para: Set element is used to group books from one series to allow validation of crossreferences.
In normal circumstances set may not be used and book should be used to capture a single title.

section.title: Book element
section.para: Book should be the default top-level (root) element for a title.
The DK book model follows docbook specification, although it does not allow colophon and bibliography.
A version attribute must be used to indicate which version of the schema is being used (5 at the time of writing).

section.title: Book covers
section.para: Use cover element inside the info block for the book to describe the cover.
Usually this will point to an image on the cover, in which case use mediaobject.
Where two or more different covers are used for different outputs, use multiple cover elements with the appropriate condition attribute.

section.title: Bibliographic information
section.para: Where a book includes a bibliography, mark-up using simple structural elements as appropriate (e.g. appendix or article) with a with a role="bibliography" attribute value.
To annotate bibliographic information associated with the whole book, use the following bibliographic elements inside the info block:
Use biblioid with attribute class set to "ISBN" to indicate the ISBN number of the book.
To capture multiple ISBN numbers for different editions of the book (such as printed vs ebook), use multiple biblioid elements with condition attribute and group the together using biblioset element.

section.title: Revision history
section.para: To capture the revision history of the printed book, use revhistory element.

section.title: Authors, editors and publisher
section.para: To capture the information about the main author, use a single author element inside the info block.
To capture multiple authors, editors contributors etc, use multiple author and editor elements and group them together using authorgroup element.

section.title: Appendices, copyright page, acknowledgments, inside covers
section.para: Any front or back-matter book level construct that does not fit into the standard part / chapter / section structure should be captured using the appendix element.
Use the role attribute to indicate the type of content captured, for example acknowledgments (see ).

section.title: Chapter
section.para: chapter should be the default top-level book division for content that runs over more than a single spread. It may contain a number of section elements, or nested section elements if more granular division is required.

section.title: Part elements
section.para: Part elements are used to indicate parts of the book. They should only be used when there are distinctive parts of the book above chapter level. If there is only one level of hierarchy, chapter elements should be used.

section.title: Article
section.para: Article should only be used immediately below the part or book level, and for portions of information that can be used standalone.
Article is sometimes equivalent to a page spread.
Nested article or an article inside a chapter is not allowed. If such a division is deemed to be helpful, use section instead and apply the role attribute with a value 'article'.

section.title: Glossary
section.para: Glossary would normally be used as a child of the book element.
If a glossary occurs at a lower level (such as chapter or article), use glosslist.

section.title: Section elements
section.para: Section elements are used to create logical subdivisions and to reflect the structure of the book.
Section elements can be nested. It may be helpful to use stylesheets (XSLT ot CSS) or XML editing tool functions to ensure that the nesting is correct.

It not recommended to use section elements with an empty title but if a structural split is necessary and no appropriate title can be give, use empty title element. This, among other things can impede the work tools such as PDF, ebook, TOC generation.
The role attribute can be used to specify functions of a section (see ).
role="feature" can be used to indicate standalone portions of information that can not be captured using article or sidebar.
role="entry" can be used to capture blocks equivalent to reference book entries.
role="article" can be used to capture blocks equivalent to standalone articles in a book.

section.title: Sidebar
section.para: sidebar should only be used to capture simple portions of information that are separated from the main flow of text.
In more complex scenarios, where additional structure needs to be captured, use section with role="feature" attribute value.

section.title: Title Abbreviations
section.para: Use the titleabbrev element in block constructs such as section if there is a need to capture an abbreviated version of a title.
Note this should not be used in place of xreflabel (see ).

section.title: Cross-references
section.para: The xref element with the linkend attribute should be used to for internal document links and cross-references. This will allow the link text to be generated from the target element (usually from the title text).
Cross-references should point to the block elements such as article or section and not their respective title elements.
If an alternative or abbreviated link text is needed, use xreflabel attribute on the target element.
See metadata section for instances where the content linked by a xref should be meta-tagged.
Use the link element with the linkend attribute when the rendering of the cross-reference should not be generated.
For external links (such as a website url) use link with a xlink:href attribute.
If useful to mark-up a website url semantically, but render as a plain text string, use the uri element.

formalpara.title: Cross-references to ranges
formalpara.para: Where a cross-reference points to a span of content that can not be naturallry wrapped in a structural element such as section, use range elements to delimit the span of content and cross-reference the start of that range. Follow range specification to create such a range.

section.title: Footnotes
section.para: To capture footnotes use footnote element inline in the text.
The whole content of the footnote should be captured within the footnote element.

The footnote element usually generates a mark (a superscript symbol or number) at the place in the flow of the document in which it occurs. The body of the footnote is then presented elsewhere, typically at the bottom of the page.

section.title: Mathematical formulas, fractions, ranges and units
section.para: informalequation and mathphrase element should be used to capture simple mathematical values, formulas, numbers, fractions, equations and similar numerical expressions.
Role attribute on the mathphrase can be used to indicate parts of the expression such as fraction.
For non inline math, use equation element
For complex formulas use MathML or mediaobject to provide verbatim rendering.
alt element inside the equation or inlineequation can be used to indicate the most simple form of the expression.

section.title: Ranges
section.para: Use range element to indicate the beginning and the end of a range.
Alternatively use phrase element to indicate the beginning and the end of a small, inline range, for example range.
Use class="startofrange" and xml:id attribute to indicate the beginning of a range.
Use class="endofrange" and startref attribute to point to the xml:id of the start of a range and indicate the end of a range.

section.title: Units
section.para: In the event that it is necessary to apply very granular tagging to numerical values (such as weights and measures), use phrase element to isolate each value, and metaref attribute and a metadata preset item/group to define the standard unit of measurement.
For example, units of measure as defined by International System of Units (SI) may be added as an item/group in metadata preset XML.

Note it is not expected that such granular tagging will be the norm. Often it is better (and far-less labour intensive), to isolate these values programmatically (e.g. through a regular expression algorithm), than to tag each value upfront.
See and .

section.title: Highlighting, emphasis, page breaks and presentational markup
section.para: DK-Schema is meant to be presentation neutral, so that the content can be repurposed to many outpus such as ebooks, audiobooks, apps etc.
Therefore it is not receommended to be too prescriptive about the presentation of content - it makes the XML verbose and makes repurposing less flexible.
In the justifiable cases, a limited set of presentational markup is allowed to hint the rendering systems as to how to display the content.

section.title: rend attribute
section.para: The rend attribute can be used to give a hint to the rendering engine as to how the text may be displayed (e.g. bold or italic).
The rend is equivalent to HTML class attribute.
Follow CSS3 W3C specification and use CSS3 selectors as available rend atrrbitue values. Note that not all values will be recognised or uspported on all rendering platforms.
The rend attribute can contain multiple, space sparated values such as rend='bold italic break-after'

section.title: Page breaks and line breaks
section.para: It is not supported to put explicit page or line breaks in the DK-Schema.
Wherever possible, use appropriate semantic structures such as section or para so that the rendering systems can infer the layout from the structure of the document.
In cases, where the default behaviour has to be overriden, use rend attribute and CSS selectors such as page-break-after to suggest the desired rendering behaviour.

section.title: Emphasis
section.para: Use emphasis element to capture text that should have a different visual representation.

section.title: Lists
section.para: Care must be taken in choosing the most simple and appropriate list type.
simplelist should be sufficient in majority of the cases. The type attribute can be used to further specify the presenetation of the list.
itemizedlist should normally be used for bulleted lists.
A phrase element can be used to highlight a heading or a keyword inside a list.
Variablelist should only be used to represent a list of term definitions.

segmentedlists should only be used as a simple alternative to represent lists or series of data and only in basic cases where there are no empty fields (cells) and there is a one to one mapping between every item in the segmented list and its associated heading.
The following list types are allowed in DK-Schema:

listitem.para: An undecorated list of single words or short phrases.
A list in which each entry is marked with a bullet or other dingbat.
That bullet or dingbat can be specified via mark attribute that point to the URI of the image.
A list in which each entry is marked with a sequentially incremented label.
It possible to specify orderedlist label to be arabic, roman and alphabetic, using numeration attribute.
The continuation attribute can specify to continue, restart or inherit the numbering from previous or parent list.
For more details please refer to The Definitive Guide Ordered List page.
A list in which each entry is composed of a set of one or more terms and an associated description.
A segmented list, a list of sets of elements.

section.title: Keys
section.para: A key is a textual or a graphical list that is referred from another location in the document.
To capture a key use variablelist with attribute role="key".

Attribute xreflabel can be used to define a title of the key (variablelist) or the key entry (listitem). If no value is specified, a default word "Key" may be rendered by the transformation toolkit in place of the xref.
Variablelist for key must have an xml:id attribute.
All the varlistentry elements must have xml:id attribute.
If the key lists graphics, use mediaobject inside the listitem to capture that, give that mediaobject and xml:id and link directly to that mediaobject.
The key should be placed at the beginning of the relevant XML fragment, usually the beginning of a section or a chapter or mediaobject caption.
To refer to a defined key use xref element with a role attribute, so that custom processing can applied.
Use role="keyref" to produce a link to the key.
Use role="key_include" to include/render that key or key entry where the link is.

In such case you need to verify the variablelist is allowed where you place the xref. You can chack that by simply adding the variablelist, validating and then removing the variablelist and replacing it with xref role="key_include".

section.title: Media Objects
section.para: All media such as photos, graphs and the associated annotations, heads, and captions should be captured using mediaobject element and its children.
If the graphic object must be displayed inline, use inlinemediobject.
Textobject can be used to provide a fallback text description of the object and any text that is not rendered along with the actual graphic media.
Use caption for the image captions and other text that needs to be displayed alongside the media.
For images with callouts, see .

section.title: Groups of illustrations
section.para: To logically group media objects such as illustrations use figure.
If the group of illustrations does not have a title, use informalfigure.

section.title: Callouts and annotated illustration
section.para: For images with annotations use imageobjectco inside the mediaobject and calloutlist with callout elements inside.
The arearefs attribute in a callout element is mandatory to uniquely identify a callout.
areaspec is an optional element available for use recording the areas on a graphic that a callout relates to.
When an areaspec is defined it will associate the callout with an area of an image.

Alternatively, where the XML fragment describing portions of the illustration can be used standalone, use separate section elements, outside of the mediaobject to describe that content and put crossreferences to those section elements in the callout construct using link or xref.

section.title: Procedure
section.para: Use procedure element to capture all lists where order is important, such as 'step by step', cooking instructions and other types of sequences.
When the numbering needs to be preserved rather than generated, please use phrase element with a role="stepnum" to specify the glyph associated with the step.

section.title: Phrase
section.para: Where possible, use the best matching inline element to capture meaning; for instance foreignphrase for latin words.
Where no useful element is present, the phrase element and an appropriate role attribute value can be used.
It may be useful to combine phrase with dk metadata attributes; see metadata section.
The phrase element may be used to indicate an inline heading or keywords.

section.title: Paragraphs
section.para: para element is the default element to represent blocks of text.
DK Schema para element is equivalent to a Docbook simplepara model.
para should only contain text and inline formatting elements.
para should not contain structural elements such as section.
para should not contain block level elements such as blockquote and in such cases additional blocks should be captured outside of para element.

section.title: Formal Paragraph
section.para: A formal paragraph - formalpara should be used to capture blocks of text with an inline title or a heading.
formalpara requires that both title and para elements are present and non-empty.
In cases where both the title and the para are not always consistently present, a para with a phrase should be used to capture the content.

section.title: Questions and Answers (Q&A)
section.para: To handle sets of questions and answers, use Docbook qandaset model.
Use qandaentry for each entry and question and answer respectively.

section.title: Tables
section.para: CALS Table format is used to capture any tabular data.
CALS Table model allows for complex table structures such as colspan and rowspan and it is easy to convert to alternative representations such as HTML Table or CSV.
Table should only be used to capture actual tabular data such as statistics or similar two-dimensional data-representations.
Table should not be used for presentational purposes only such as fixing layout issues.
Use informaltable if the table has no title that is visible and should be rendered or normal table element for a table with a title.
Use tgroup to specify number of columns and default formatting.

Colspec is optional and is used to specify the width, sequence etc of a column. It is required if you're defining column spans. If you are declaring a colspec, do so for all columns and you have to provide colname for all columns.
Use namest and namend attributes on entry element to specify cells spanning multiple columns.
Use morerows attribute to specify vertical spans.
For all other cases please refer to TDG section on CALS and CALS Table Model Specification.

section.title: Quotations
section.para: Use quote element to capture inline quotations, citations and similar text structures.
Use blockquote to capture quotations that are logically separate from the rest of the text and should be rendered as a separate block.
Where quotation is the first element in a chapter, article or a similar division, this is usally an epigraph and should be captured as an epigraph element.
Do not include literal quotation characters in quotes. Their appeareance can be controlled when publishing via XSL or otherwise.

section.title: Profiling
section.para: Profiling is a technique to conditionally filter out portions of XML.
Use condition attribute on an element to mark it for profiling.
This is done by applying a condition attribute at the lowest possible level.
If there is no suitable element to apply the profiling, wrap the XML or text fragment in a phrase element, to keep it at the lowest level.
Every element that has profiling applied (condition attribute) needs to have a cref attribute to uniquely identify that XML portion.
If two blocks of XML represent the same content for different outputs, they need to have the same cref attribute value.
Nesting of profiling should be avoided in general to prevent confusing results. Nesting for the same type of condition will not work.
For example if a whole sentence is marked as print only (condition="prt") and a word inside as digital, the digital part will never show up in digital output as the whole sentence is profiled out.
Profiling should be used sparsely and only where necessary as it duplicates the XML and can have unforeseen consequences.

Linking: Conditional content might get stripped upon profiling. if possible links should point to parent element that isn't profiled. If that's not possible, stylesheet should translate links to the equivalent elements by matching on cref values.
Appropriate use cases include:

simplelist.member: Output specific content: print vs digital. In this case point links and xrefs to digital variant or parent element.
Imperial vs Metric measurements. In this case, it can be decided to include only Metric

section.title: Using rend, role and metaref attributes

listitem.para: Attribute rend should be used for clearly presentational purposes (equivalent to HMTL class attribute) free form and can include multiple (space separated) values
Attribute role should be used for semantic mark-up and re-defines or adds to the semantics of the element to which it is applied.
Only one value is allowed, and DK-Schema does not maintain an enumerated list of allowed values in the schema.

It is assumed that in most cases more detailed values can entirely replace less detailed values without loss of meaning e.g. the default value role='feature' can be replaced with role='human impact' and serve the same purpose.
In the event that an element must have more that one semantic term associated with it metaref and meta.xml categorisation must be used.
to be used to associate phrases or blocks with terms described in a term/subject classification taxonomy, which is itself defined in meta.xml.
meta.xml classification can be created on request, but this needs to go through the schema working group who will advise on its design.

section.title: Role attribute
section.para: The role attribute may be used re-define the semantics of any docbook element, this may occur on block and inline elements
It may be useful to combine role with dk metadata attributes; see metadata section.
The enumeration of role values and rules for their usage will be validated with a DK schematron.
Currently the following role values are allowed:

listitem.para: Used on section below the chapter level element to indicate content that is standalone.
For high-level chunks of content you can still use article element.
This constructs is used instead of a dedicated article element, to simplify processing and make XML more consistent.
Typically, if the XML is sourced from a printed book, section with role article is equivalent to a two-page spread in a book.
To be used on section element to indicate a small chunk of content that is standalone, potentially resuable and related to the subject of the parent section/topic..

Content that contains a directory of contact addresses, further information, phone book listing etc. should be captured with a role attribute indicating a directory entry container element. See for more details.
Used to indicate individual directory entries. See
Used to group and subdivide directory entries. See
Used on section below the chapter level element to wrap standalone illustration that do not belong to any particular section of text..
See for more information
Such section must not have a title of it's own - used textobject of the child mediaobject.
Used on the first para element of a given section.
Use this to indicate introductory paragraph of a given chunk of content.
See
See
Used on the first phrase element of a given para.
Use this to indicate introductory sentence of a paragraph.
Used on section below the chapter level element to wrap standalone maps that do not belong to any particular section of text.
See for more information
Such section must not have a title of it's own - use textobject of the child mediaobject.
Use on linking elements such as xref and link.
Use this to indicate that this a particular type of link that is pointing to an area of a map.
Used on the para element.
Use this to indicate that this portion of text is a note.
Use only on the phrase element that is part of an index.
Use this to point index entries to patricular page numbers in a printed book.
Use only on the first para element in a section.
By default the tile of the current chapter and section will be the running head. Use this to specify a different running head.
Use only on the section element to indicate a timeline.
Use this role to indicate a chunk of content that spans a period of time.
Use only on the section or para element to indicate an entry in a timeline.
Use only on the para element to indicate that the paragraphs is a description of an entry in a timeline.

section.para: If you need to introduce a new role value, double check that the appropriate role or meta values is not already defined and contact the DK-Schema core team to update the validation tools.

section.title: Metadata Presets
section.para: A custom functionality has been introduced in DK Schema to allow straightforward classification and tagging of chunks of content using predefined presets.
Meta classification can be applied in the following ways:

varlistentry.term: meta element in an info block

listitem.para: This is the recommended behaviour. This means that the metadata will apply the the whole block.
Multiple meta elements are allowed.
Use metaref and point to the xml:id in the meta classification defined in the meta.xml
If the meta classification needs to be applied for a small portion of XML use metaref attribute on any element.
If there is no suitable element, use phrase element with a metaref attribute.

If a xref element is used to generate an image or text found in a key (see keys), and it is desirable to further classify the key information with metadata, the metaref attribute must be applied to the xref element.

section.para: The descriptions of the available and allowed meta values are in the Meta XML file.

section.title: Meta XML file
section.para: The meta classification presets are stored in the meta.xml and can be extended by adhering to the meta.rnc RelaxNG schema.
The meta.xml file has a number of item and group elements that define a given classification.
At minimum every item and group needs to have a unique xml:id attribute that will be used to refer to that classification from individual XML files as well as a name.
description helps by giving more details about a given classification.
source identifies the origin of classification, for example: "Rough Guides", "Navteq", "Natural History DB" etc..

section.title: Geocoding
section.para: In order to associate geographic location with a portion of XML lat and long attributes are allowed on most elements.

section.title: Customization
section.para: From the very beginning, one of the goals of DK-Schema has been that users should be able to produce customizations that are either subsets of extensions of common Dk-Schema.
In DK-Schema v2, we hope to take advantage of RELAX NGs more robust design (and it's lack of pernicious determinism rules) to make customization easier.
Three schema design patterns in the underlying DocBook v5 design get us most of the way there.

section.title: Logical Groupings
section.para: DocBook elements, particularly the inlines, can be divided into broad classes: general purpose, technical, error-related, operating-system related, bibliographic, publishing, etc. In DocBook V5.0, these are collected together in named patterns.

To add a new inline, endpoint for example, to the list of technical inlines, one need only extend the appropriate pattern. If an element should appear in several classes, they can all be extended in the same way:
section.programlisting: db.technical.inlines |= endpoint db.programming.inlines |= endpoint db.os.inlines |= endpoint
section.para: Much the same concept was used in DocBook V4.x, where instead of patterns we had parameter entities. However, the constraints of DTD validation severely limit the circumstances under which an element can appear twice in a content model. That meant that adding an element to one parameter entity might make it an error to add it to another. Such constraints do not exist in RELAX NG which greatly simplifies the customization.

section.title: Element Definitions
section.para: Each element in DocBook V5.0 is defined by its own pattern. To change the content model of an element, only that pattern need be redefined. To remove an element from DocBook, that pattern can be redefined as notAllowed.

section.title: Attribute Definitions
section.para: Each attribute list in DocBook V5.0 is defined by its own pattern. To change the list of attributes available on an element, only that pattern need be redefined. To remove all the attributes, that pattern can be redefined as empty.

section.title: When to use?
section.para: Phrase Book variant should be used for all phrasebooks, dictionaries and multilingual content.
It allows typical Common DK-Schema content plus phrase book specific content based on TEI P5 dictionary model.
If no specific phrasebook element exists, use equivalent Common DK-Schema / Docbook element, for example quote.

To clarify the usage the following should be established:
What is the native language of the audience?
This language should be considered local.
Any portions of phrase entries in the local language should normally be captured inside structure and its children such as regardless of the order of appearance.
What is the language the audience doesn't understand?
This language should be considered foreign.
Any portions of phrase entries in the foreign language should normally be captured inside structure and its children such as regardless of the order of appearance.

For example in a book for English readers with foreign phrases in German, all German phrases should be captured inside structure and its children and their English equivalents inside structure and its children.
For more information on TEI p5 architecture please go to: TEI Reference

section.title: Phrase Entry
section.para: This is the main block and wrapper for a phrase entry.
A typical phrase entry should ideally consist of at least one portion in the source language using the form element and at least one portion in target language using the sense element.

section.title: Crossreferencing phrase entries
section.para: Whenever there is a crossreference inside a phrase_entry element, use standard Docbook linking elements:
Use xref for links to other portions of XML and link to point ot non-resolvable destination such as pages or parts of an image.
A role attribute value of role="phrase_entry_include" can be used to specify that the link phrase entry or its portion should be copied and included inline.
A role attribute value of role="phrase_entry_ref" can be used to specify that the link phrase entry or its portion should be referenced and a hyperlink created.

section.title: Phrase Form
section.para: Form element groups all the information on the written and spoken forms of one headword.
Form should be used to capture content foreign to the audience, for more explanation go to:
For more information on TEI p5 form please go to: TEI Form Reference

section.title: Inline Phrase Entry
section.para: This is the inline version of a phrase entry.
See for a full definition.
The inline version of the phrase entry is to be used inside blocks such as or tables and the processing systems will by default not introduce any newlines or formatting.

section.title: Phrase Sense
section.para: Sense element groups together all information relating to one word sense in a dictionary entry, for example definitions, examples, and translation equivalents.
Form should be used to capture content local to the audience, for more explanation go to:
Whenever possible use def to include the definition or the translation of the phrase.
For more information on TEI p5 sense please go to: TEI Sense Reference

section.title: Phrase Definition
section.para: Def element contains definition text in a dictionary entry.
Whenever possible use def inside sense element to include the definition or the translation of the phrase.
For more information on TEI p5 def please go to: TEI Def Reference

section.title: Phrase Usage
section.para: Usg element contains usage or an example of a phrase text in an entry.
Whenever possible use usg inside sense element to include the usage of the phrase.
For more information on TEI p5 usg please go to: TEI Usg Reference

section.title: Phrase Ortographic Form
section.para: Orth gives the orthographic form of a dictionary headword or a phrase.
Use orth to capture the main form of the phrase in the original or source language.
Whenever possible use orth inside form element.
For more information on TEI p5 orth please go to: TEI Orth Reference

section.title: Phrase Pronounciation
section.para: Pron contains the pronunciation(s) of the word.
Whenever possible use pron inside form element.
For more information on TEI p5 pron please go to: TEI Pron Reference

section.title: Grammatical Classification
section.para: Every phrase entry can be classified in the context of part of speech, number and gender. This classification should only be applied once in a given Phrase_entry element.
The classification should be grouped under gramGrp element.

The predefined classifications are:
partofspeech phrase_number phrase_gender
If necssary further classification can be specified by using phrase with a role attribute inside a gramGrp element.

section.title: Using Cookery Module
section.para: DK Schema Cookery variant should be used to capture any book containing recipies.
Typicaly, each recipe should be captured using recipe.
Recipe needs to have a title and details about the recipe itself, such as:
Capture any additional information such as serving size or preparation time using metaref or .

section.title: Ingredients
section.para: A block containing a listing of ingredients used in a recipe.
Identify each individual ingredient using role="ingredient" attribute.
Use metaref attribute to identify units of measurement, see for more information.
Use to distinguish between imperial and metric units.

section.title: Nutrition
section.para: Whenever possible, capture the nutritional information about the recipe and its ingredients, such as calories count, amount of fat, sodium, etc.
If possible, wrap all nutrition information in a nutrition element.
Identify each individual nutritional ingredient using role="nutrition" attribute and metaref attribute from "nutrition" meta group.

section.title: Preparation
section.para: Preparation is the block for capturing the actual procedure of meal or recipe preparation, divided into steps.

An individual prepration step should be captured using step element. If it is necessary to explicitly indicate the step number, use the stepnum attribute, otherwise the numbering will be generated automatically.

section.title: Tagging DK Travel content
section.para: Typically, it should be possible to mark travel content using common DK-Schema. Additional layers of information can be added using for metadata, and, when necessary rend for presentational information.
Specifically, it should be done as follows:

step.title: Create high-level structure
step.para: Use standard Docbook / DK-schema elements to create the desired structure of the document - parts, chapters, section for traditional book structure.
If using topic-based authoring, create individual topics first and then assemble them together into a final structure, using Docbook Assembly mechanism.

step.title: Create inline markup
step.para: Mark up inline elements using a combination of standard Docbook elements and custom DK role attribute values to highlight specific, smaller chunks of content such as notes, features, etc.

step.title: Apply Travel Metadata
step.para: To indicate particular chunks of content use meta element (for block elements such as sections or topics) in the info block.
For smaller, inline chunks such as as phrases use metaref attribute.
The descriptions of the available and allowed meta values are in the Meta XML file.

step.title: (Optional) Add presentational information
step.para: When absolutely necessary to satisfy project or product requirements, apply additional, presentation-specific information using .
This is not recommended as it may make the production of future projects more difficult.

section.title: DK Schema Version 2.0
section.para: This is the new version of the schema based on Docbook v5.x Publisher Subcommittee draft and it focuses on good interoperability with the Core Docbook schema.

section.title: DK Schema Version 1.0
section.para: This is the intial version of the schema based on: Docbook v4.x DTD, TEI, CALS and other industry standards
